h4.a: CMCSS Schools Closed for the Rest of the 2019-2020 School Year

div.style: height: 280px; width: 100%; background-image: url(https://cmcss.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/3.png); background-size: cover; background-position: center; margin-top: -16px;

br.span: This page provides guidance on Continued Learning Resources available during the closure due to COVID-19. Children thrive within structured environments, and it will be important to provide opportunities during the day for your children to be creative, read and discuss what they are reading, and participate in physical activity. It is a good idea to create a daily structure in... READ MORE

div.style: height: 280px; width: 100%; background-image: url(https://cmcss.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1.png); background-size: cover; background-position: center; margin-top: -16px;

br.span: Over the past few weeks, a Communicable Disease Team (CDT) comprised of leaders from CMCSS and the Montgomery County Health Department have been meeting regularly to review the latest guidance from the CDC, monitor the health and attendance of CMCSS students and employees, and make recommendations to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 and other communicable diseases. READ MORE

div.style: height: 280px; width: 100%; background-image: url(https://cmcss.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/2.png); background-size: cover; background-position: center; margin-top: -16px;

br.span: Effective Monday, March 23 until further notice, meals for children will be served Monday, Wednesday and Friday from 10 a.m. to noon at the following locations: Barkers Mill Elementary, Barksdale Elementary, Burt Elementary, Byrns Darden Elementary, Cumberland Heights Elementary, Glenellen Elementary, Kenwood Elementary, Minglewood Elementary, Moore Elementary, Norman Smith Elementary, Ringgold Elementary, and Woodlawn Elementary and Kenwood High, Montgomery Central... READ MORE

p.span:
On Monday, April 20, we begin week three of our Continued Learning Resources. Although school buildings will be closed for the remainder of the 2019-20 academic year, learning will not stop for our students. Teachers will continue reaching out to students and parents on a weekly basis, and the CMCSS Continued Learning Library (sites.google.com/cmcss.net/cmcsscontinuedlearninglibrary/home) will be updated with resources through the week of May 18. Additionally, the supplemental At-Home Learning Resources (sites.google.com/cmcss.net/cmcssathomelearningresources/home) will continue to be available through the summer. We encourage families to keep using the Live Assist feature on the Continued Learning Library or the CMCSS Help Hotline at 931.920.7779 for assistance.
Printed learning packets will still be available at our meal distribution sites for those who need them. Next week, we will temporarily consolidate our distribution of printed packets to the following sites: Barksdale Elementary, Cumberland Heights Elementary, Kenwood Elementary and Northeast High School. In addition to these sites, we also have extended hours for packet distribution at the Onsite Clinic, Monday through Friday from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Kenwood Elementary on Monday and Wednesday from 5 to 7 p.m. Full distribution will resume the week of April 27. Please note that this temporary change is only for printed packets and will not change the meal distribution sites, which have served over 270,000 meals since the closure and will continue to serve children 18 and under through May 22.
We want to take this opportunity to address or reiterate a few important topics:
• Grades - On April 9, the State Board of Education determined that no student will be issued a grade lower than what had been earned as of March 20, 2020. Grades for high school credit-bearing courses have unique circumstances, so parents should reach out to teachers or administrators with questions. Parents at any grade level should contact your child’s teacher or administrator if you have concerns about grades.
• Promotion/Graduation - Students who were on track to be promoted to the next grade level or graduate as of March 20, 2020 will do so. Teachers, counselors, and/or administrators have already reached out if your child was at risk of not graduating or being promoted. There are concerns across the nation and world that this gap in classroom instruction will cause students in Pre-K through 11th grade to not be prepared for the 2020-21 school year. Our Curriculum and Instruction Department has provided the standards-based Continued Learning Library to help close this gap, and they will continue to refine the curriculum plans for the 2020-21 school year to ensure students are on track. Please contact your child’s teacher or administrator if you have concerns about promotion or graduation.
• Returning Items/Personal Belongings - CMCSS is developing a plan to allow students and parents at all school levels to retrieve items left at school and return school-owned items. We are monitoring stay-at-home orders and social distancing guidelines. When it is safe and healthy to do so, we will communicate specific dates and times for this process.
Finally, we want to acknowledge that this situation is emotionally challenging for both children and adults. If your child needs assistance with processing their emotions, students in 3rd through 12th grade still have access to the counselor self-referral system. Parents of a child in any grade may reach out directly to the school counselor or can ask a teacher to refer them. Additionally, if you, your child, or someone in your home is experiencing a crisis, text HOME to 741741 or call 800-273-TALK (8255) to connect with someone who is there to help. We are all in this together, and we must help each other navigate through these challenges.

img.alt:
On Monday, April 20, we begin week three of our Continued Learning Resources. Although school buildings will be closed for the remainder of the 2019-20 academic year, learning will not stop for our students. Teachers will continue reaching out to students and parents on a weekly basis, and the CMCSS Continued Learning Library (https://sites.google.com/cmcss.net/cmcsscontinuedlearninglibrary/home) will be updated with resources through the week of May 18. Additionally, the supplemental At-Home Learning Resources (https://sites.google.com/cmcss.net/cmcssathomelearningresources/home) will continue to be available through the summer. We encourage families to keep using the Live Assist feature on the Continued Learning Library or the CMCSS Help Hotline at 931.920.7779 for assistance.
Printed learning packets will still be available at our meal distribution sites for those who need them. Next week, we will temporarily consolidate our distribution of printed packets to the following sites: Barksdale Elementary, Cumberland Heights Elementary, Kenwood Elementary and Northeast High School. In addition to these sites, we also have extended hours for packet distribution at the Onsite Clinic, Monday through Friday from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Kenwood Elementary on Monday and Wednesday from 5 to 7 p.m. Full distribution will resume the week of April 27. Please note that this temporary change is only for printed packets and will not change the meal distribution sites, which have served over 270,000 meals since the closure and will continue to serve children 18 and under through May 22.
We want to take this opportunity to address or reiterate a few important topics: • Grades - On April 9, the State Board of Education determined that no student will be issued a grade lower than what had been earned as of March 20, 2020. Grades for high school credit-bearing courses have unique circumstances, so parents should reach out to teachers or administrators with questions. Parents at any grade level should contact your child’s teacher or administrator if you have concerns about grades. • Promotion/Graduation - Students who were on track to be promoted to the next grade level or graduate as of March 20, 2020 will do so. Teachers, counselors, and/or administrators have already reached out if your child was at risk of not graduating or being promoted. There are concerns across the nation and world that this gap in classroom instruction will cause students in Pre-K through 11th grade to not be prepared for the 2020-21 school year. Our Curriculum and Instruction Department has provided the standards-based Continued Learning Library to help close this gap, and they will continue to refine the curriculum plans for the 2020-21 school year to ensure students are on track. Please contact your child’s teacher or administrator if you have concerns about promotion or graduation. • Returning Items/Personal Belongings - CMCSS is developing a plan to allow students and parents at all school levels to retrieve items left at school and return school-owned items. We are monitoring stay-at-home orders and social distancing guidelines. When it is safe and healthy to do so, we will communicate specific dates and times for this process.
Finally, we want to acknowledge that this situation is emotionally challenging for both children and adults. If your child needs assistance with processing their emotions, students in 3rd through 12th grade still have access to the counselor self-referral system. Parents of a child in any grade may reach out directly to the school counselor or can ask a teacher to refer them. Additionally, if you, your child, or someone in your home is experiencing a crisis, text HOME to 741741 or call 800-273-TALK (8255) to connect with someone who is there to help. We are all in this together, and we must help each other navigate through these challenges.

p.span:
Good Afternoon CMCSS Students,
Your teachers and school staff would like to take a moment each day to say hello and encourage you. Check back with us each weekday to see the faces we know you have been missing. They are most certainly missing you!
#cmcss
#schoolsystem
#cmcssmissesyou
#cmcssstrong

div.span: This 10-year-old seamstress is using her talent to help the community during the COVID-19 pandemic.

div.p: The official Instagram account of the Clarksville-Montgomery County School System.

a.span: March is Youth Art Month. CMCSS students celebrate

img.alt: March is Youth Art Month. CMCSS students celebrate by showcasing their masterpieces at the Montgomery County Library. #cmcss #youthartmonth #SES

a.span: Four years ago, Kimberly Bellamy began bringing go

img.alt: Four years ago, Kimberly Bellamy began bringing golden retrievers registered with Pet Partners animal therapy program to classrooms in CMCSS. With the three dogs combined, Mrs. Bellamy has visited CMCSS schools 140 times, which amounts to over 200 hours. They have visited 14 elementary schools, 2 middle schools, 2 high schools; in addition to the Synergy Program and the Learning Center. Visits have been related to "animals in the community" lessons, behavior incentives, and socialization for CDC students as well. But the majority of visits are to strengthen reading confidence using the student-animal bond. There is no judgment from a dog. Charlie, Skiff and Penny are their names. The Bellamy dogs are registered with the Pet Partners animal therapy program, and each have to pass the evaluation every two years. Significant training goes in to preparing for the test, but more importantly, the animal has to have the temperament to be a therapy dog. They have to enjoy meeting new people and have excellent manners in public. Charlie and Skiff have almost equal number of visits. Penny has just 18 visits with CMCSS. Richview Middle School teacher Michelle Main and West Creek Elementary School teacher Karma Sherk have consistently invited Mrs. Bellamy to their classrooms on a monthly basis, year after year. They have seen what an effect it has on their students and have been so committed to participating. #cmcss #wces #Charlie #therapydogs

a.span: Students from the Academy of Teaching and Learning

img.alt: Students from the Academy of Teaching and Learning at WCHS work with students at WCES on a weekly basis. #cmcss #elementaryschool #highschool #academy #WCHS #WCES

a.span: Parachute day smiles are the best. #cmcss #element

img.alt: Parachute day smiles are the best. #cmcss #elementaryschool #parachuteday #KES #PE

Visits have been related to "animals in the community" lessons, behavior incentives, and socialization for CDC students as well. But the majority of visits are to strengthen reading confidence using the student-animal bond. There is no judgment from a dog. Charlie, Skiff and Penny are their names. The Bellamy dogs are registered with the Pet Partners animal therapy program, and each have to pass the evaluation every two years. Significant training goes in to preparing for the test, but more importantly, the animal has to have the temperament to be a therapy dog. They have to enjoy meeting new people and have excellent manners in public. Charlie and Skiff have almost equal number of visits. Penny has just 18 visits with CMCSS. Richview Middle School teacher Michelle Main and West Creek Elementary School teacher Karma Sherk have consistently invited Mrs. Bellamy to their classrooms on a monthly basis, year after year.
